image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says the company has not identifed the root cause of the outage affecting millions of Australians, while there is "no indication" it has been caused by a cyber attack. Follow live.

title.children: Optus has not identified cause of major outage, 'will not rest' until services back online

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Communication Workers Union — the union that represents telecommunications workers — says that today’s outage is a "disgrace". It put out a statement saying the company has cut more than 600 jobs from its workforce in the past 12 months. Here's a few snippets from Communication Workers Union national assistant secretary James Perkins's statement: "When you repeatedly slash jobs and outsource critical services to contracting companies – this is what happens. "Australians deserve better than to have one of the major national carriers leave them in the dark for hours, with no answers. "Slashing your workforce has a direct impact on quality of service – and we're seeing the impact of that today. "We call on Optus to walk back on their job cuts and make a commitment to their workforce of no more redundancies. "The Australian community deserves better from Optus."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Union criticises Optus for 'slashing' jobs

children.content: The Communication Workers Union — the union that represents telecommunications workers — says that today’s outage is a "disgrace".
It put out a statement saying the company has cut more than 600 jobs from its workforce in the past 12 months.
Here's a few snippets from Communication Workers Union national assistant secretary James Perkins's statement:
"When you repeatedly slash jobs and outsource critical services to contracting companies – this is what happens.
"Australians deserve better than to have one of the major national carriers leave them in the dark for hours, with no answers.
"Slashing your workforce has a direct impact on quality of service – and we're seeing the impact of that today.
"We call on Optus to walk back on their job cuts and make a commitment to their workforce of no more redundancies.
"The Australian community deserves better from Optus."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We've not heard anything official from Optus yet. But I'm seeing a lot of comments from people saying they're back online: internet seems to be back on (Moss Vale, NSW) — William Optus seems to be back online now. — Stephen My service is back up in Armidale NSW. — Armidale I am in Queensland and I just got access back — two bars have replaced SOS — Trixie 3G has just been restored to me (Melbourne CBD) — Carlos
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some readers report being back online

children.content: We've not heard anything official from Optus yet.
But I'm seeing a lot of comments from people saying they're back online:
internet seems to be back on (Moss Vale, NSW)
— William
Optus seems to be back online now.
— Stephen
My service is back up in Armidale NSW.
— Armidale
I am in Queensland and I just got access back — two bars have replaced SOS
— Trixie
3G has just been restored to me (Melbourne CBD)
— Carlos

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Communications Minister Michelle Rowland held a press conference a few minutes ago. She was asked about the cause of the outage. Unfortunately, we don't have any answers yet. Here's what Ms Rowland says "My understanding is that this is a fault deep in the core. "The core network basically encompasses everything from routing to electronics. "So it is a fault that is quite fundamental to the network. "But my understanding, having just recently spoken again to the CEO, is that a number of problems have been identified, and that Optus continues to work on this."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Communications minister: Outage due to 'deep fault'

children.content: Communications Minister Michelle Rowland
held a press conference a few minutes ago.
She was asked about the cause of the outage.
Unfortunately, we don't have any answers yet.
Here's what Ms
Rowland says
"My understanding is that this is a fault deep in the core.
"The core network basically encompasses everything from routing to electronics.
"So it is a fault that is quite fundamental to the network.
"But my understanding, having just recently spoken again to the CEO, is that a number of problems have been identified, and that Optus continues to work on this."

image.altText: A group of customers surround a retail worker inside of a shop

items.synopsis: Optus says it is working to solve the issue impacting mobile and internet customers, with services down since early this morning across the country.

title.children: 'No indication' cyber attack behind Optus outage, CEO says

title.children: Lawyer for driver in Daylesford crash says man is insulin-dependent diabetic who needed immediate treatment

title.children: Cricket world in awe of Maxwell as Indian legend Tendulkar lauds stunning knock as the best he's ever seen

image.altText: Clare stands outside wearing a bright red blazer.

items.synopsis: Clare is autistic and was struggling to fit in at school, but when life went online in the pandemic, things improved. Experts say she's not alone.

title.children: Clare used to worry she was 'too much'. When school went online, things got better

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg releases first public statement after release

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg was released from prison in June after being pardoned over the deaths of her four children. A final report after an inquiry into her convictions was released on Wednesday.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg case referred for possible appeal after final conviction report released

image.altText: Palestinian family reacts following Israeli airstrike

items.synopsis: At least 500 more people, most of them foreign nationals, cross into Egypt after the Rafah border crossing re-opens, while an Israeli government spokesperson tells the ABC the country will have to exercise "ultimate security control" over the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: Evacuations at Rafah crossing accelerate, Israel wants to exercise 'ultimate security control' over Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC. A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7. "The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the spokesperson said. "Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels." The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another three Australians cross from Gaza to Egypt, bringing the total to 28, DFAT confirms

children.content: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC.
A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7.
"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the spokesperson said.

"Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels."
The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends. Yesterday Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu raised the prospect of Israel taking control of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated. "Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't," Eylon Levy, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told Patricia Karvelas on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words. He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised. The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said. When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated: "When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time. "We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years." Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel wants to exercise 'ultimate security control' over Gaza after war, government spokesperson says

featuredLink.title: What happens to Gaza when the conflict ends? - ABC listen

children.content: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends.
Yesterday Israeli PM
Benjamin Netanyahu
raised the prospect of Israel taking control
of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated.
"Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't,"
Eylon Levy
, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told
Patricia Karvelas
on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words.
He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised.
The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said.
When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated:
"When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time.
"We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years."
Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even before the October 7 Hamas attacks, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was in hot water. Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis. "Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country," Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn writes. "Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different. "Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century." Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dissatisfaction towards Netanyahu intensifies in Israel

featuredLink.title: 'The real problem is the guy who's our leader': Israelis are furious with PM Benjamin Netanyahu

children.content: Even before the October 7 Hamas attacks,
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
was in hot water.
Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis.
"Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country,"
Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn
writes.
"Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different.
"Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century."
Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.

items.synopsis: War began on October 7 when Hamas militants crossed from Gaza and killed 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians, and abducted more than 200. Since then, Israel has bombarded the Hamas-run strip, killing more than 10,000 people, around 40 per cent of them children, according to regional health officials.

title.children: Israel's war with Hamas enters its second month

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The union representing telecommunications workers says that today's outage is "an absolute disgrace" – leaving some of the most vulnerable members of the community relying on landlines without emergency help. The Communication Workers Union (CWU) said outage came just after Optus slashed more than 600 jobs over the past year, with about 200 of these going in the past month alone. "When you repeatedly slash jobs and outsource critical services to contracting companies – this is what happens," CWU national assistant secretary James Perkins said. "Australians deserve better than to have one of the major national carriers leave them in the dark for hours, with no answers." He said the union was worried about vulnerable members of the community and their ability to access help and emergency services on their landlines. "There are many elderly Australians who do not have a mobile phone, and this would be a very distressing day for them and their families," he said. "The Australian community deserves better from Optus." Read more on our Optus coverage across the ABC. The telecommunications giant says there's currently no indication the outage is due to a cyber attack and it was 'unlikely' due to that.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Union calls Optus outage 'disgraceful' after 600 job cuts

children.content: The union representing telecommunications workers says that today's outage is "an absolute disgrace" – leaving some of the most vulnerable members of the community relying on landlines without emergency help.
The Communication Workers Union (CWU) said outage came just after Optus slashed more than 600 jobs over the past year, with about 200 of these going in the past month alone.
"When you repeatedly slash jobs and outsource critical services to contracting companies – this is what happens," CWU national assistant secretary James Perkins said.
"Australians deserve better than to have one of the major national carriers leave them in the dark for hours, with no answers."
The Optus outage comes after 600 job cuts over the past year.
(AAP: Bianca De Marchi)
He said the union was worried about vulnerable members of the community and their ability to access help and emergency services on their landlines.
"There are many elderly Australians who do not have a mobile phone, and this would be a very distressing day for them and their families," he said.
"The Australian community deserves better from Optus."
Read more on our Optus coverage across the ABC. The telecommunications giant says there's currently
no indication the outage is due to a cyber attack
and it was 'unlikely' due to that.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I did say I might be back for a guest post or two, although I didn't expect it to be so quick. But some interesting data from employment website Seek just dropped in my inbox. Job ads on the platform just dropped 5% last month, seasonally adjusted. Job ads are now down nearly 20% compared to October last year, although they are still 16.7% higher than pre-pandemic in October 2019. September data show applications per ad continued to rise in September (there's a one-month lag on this data), up by 4.1%. The biggest falls in job ads over both the past month and the past year are in Victoria and NSW. "Nationally, a fall in job ads in Hospitality & Tourism was the biggest contributor to the overall decline followed by Trades & Services and Healthcare & Medical," noted Seek's managing director for Australia and New Zealand, Kendra Banks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Seek data show jobs ads plunging

children.content: I did say I might be back for a guest post or two, although I didn't expect it to be so quick.

Job ads are now down nearly 20% compared to October last year
, although they are still 16.7% higher than pre-pandemic in October 2019.
September data show applications per ad continued to rise in September (there's a one-month lag on this data), up by 4.1%.
The biggest falls in job ads over both the past month and the past year are in Victoria and NSW.
